Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Advanced Psychophysiological Recording System (including EEG) to Enhance Interdisciplinary Research, Education, and Training

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Electrical activity from the brain provides insights into many aspects of human experience, including mental processes about which individuals may or may not be aware. In addition, electroencephalography (EEG, which is the measurement of the brain's electrical activity from the surface of the head) provides students with an accessible introduction to neuroscience research through active learning and experimentation. Small, primarily undergraduate institutions provide a unique setting for novel, cross-disciplinary EEG research because of close interactions among students and faculty, heavy responsibility given to undergraduate students, and the unique and novel research collaborations this environment can afford. An Advanced Psychophysiological Recording System (APRS), supported by this NSF MRI award, will enable the investigators to record EEGs from the whole head of one or two individuals at a time, as well as recording other physiological activity (e.g., arousal, muscle activity). The investigators will initiate three core research projects that focus on using the APRS (primarily for measures of brain activity) to test hypotheses about emotion, attention, perception, memory, and the relationships among them. Students will see first-hand how the brain responds to activities they do every day, such as texting, recalling personal memories, and attempting to multi-task. Each project will be executed as a collaboration among faculty and students, leading to concrete scientific contributions (e.g., research presentations and publications). Beyond these core projects, faculty members will integrate the APRS into various courses to provide unique and innovative research-based experiences with the potential for generating novel research data and inspiring students (and faculty) to consider new applications of psychophysiological methods and to develop cutting-edge research projects. The APRS will enable interdisciplinary course activities and student research projects that will foster student training and productivity in basic research, as well as efforts to promote postdoctoral training in research with undergraduates and applications for additional external support for undergraduate research. Because of the large number of women and racial/ethnic minorities at the awardee institution, the placement of the APRS instrument and the collaborative use of the system will provide unique opportunities for women and minorities that are underrepresented in the sciences.

The core research goals of the project are to complete studies of (1) effects of emotion and cognitive workload (i.e., mental effort) on brain responses related to automatic attention, (2) brain activity related to interactions between emotion and personal memories, and (3) the role of emotion in brain activity related to computer-mediated communication (e.g., texting). In addition, faculty will integrate research with education by incorporating APRS-based research into research methods and independent research courses in psychology and neuroscience, by initiating student projects to detect subtle patterns in complex brain activity (engineering) and identify patterns of brain activity related to connecting with literary characters (languages and literature). Ultimately, deeply engaging undergraduate students in original scientific research with the APRS will be a critical component of each research project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Psychophysiological methods provide a unique window to mental operations, especially ones relating to processes that may be outside of conscious awareness. Electroencephalography (EEG) and event-related brain potentials (ERPs) measure neuronal activity, providing precise timing information about brain function. These techniques are widely used in research and clinical settings, but undergraduate students generally are not able to become intensively involved in laboratories with high-end EEG/ERP research systems. At larger institutions, intensive involvement tends to be limited to graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Although smaller institutions often allow for closer student-faculty interactions, they generally lack the resources and infrastructure for such research programs.

Christian Brothers University (CBU) is a primarily undergraduate university in the heart of Memphis, Tennessee. It has a diverse student body, with more than 40 percent of students identifying themselves as belonging to one or more minority groups. With a student body of fewer than 2000, students have the opportunity to work closely with faculty members.

The goal of this NSF Major Research Instrumentation award was to provide an opportunity for CBU students (and students at nearby institutions) to engage in high-level cognitive neuroscience research. This award allowed CBU to build a research laboratory and program around such a system.

Over the course of three years, 5 faculty members and 27 students (26 of whom were undergraduates) directly participated as researchers in award-related projects. In addition, an undergraduate minor in cognitive neuroscience was established with a stronger emphasis on hands-on research than many such programs in the U.S. The lab and the minor have drawn students from majors in the School of Arts (including its home department of Behavioral Sciences), as well as the Schools of Science and of Engineering. The undergraduate research team also has been supporting class-based research projects that would not otherwise be feasible to conduct as class projects.

The undergraduate researchers have varied in their level of engagement. Some students were simply involved in data collection for a semester. Others became more deeply involved, participating in research design, data analysis, and writing and presenting the research. Eight undergraduates earned authorship on at least one national or international poster or paper presentation about research in which the NSF-funded system was used. Six undergraduate students presented research themselves. These student opportunities are continuing past the duration of the NSF award.

With the award-funded system, we began a series of core research projects on emotion, attention, perception, memory, and the relationships among them. Students have presented these findings at research conferences and will be co-authors on publications. Two of the core projects led to follow-up studies—engaging several students in the continuous nature of the scientific process. The availability of the system also resulted in additional outcomes: original, student-led research projects; student grant proposals (one of which was funded); and additional faculty-led grant proposals. These efforts continue and we expect additional such outcomes well beyond the award period.

Of the students who worked with the system, at least three have entered graduate programs. Two of them began doctoral-level work in psychology (both continue to engage in neuroscience research) in fall 2017. At least two more students plan to apply to graduate school in the year following the end of the award period. Two per year represents nearly 1% of CBU graduates across all undergraduate majors. Thus, the award has led directly to the entry of qualified students into graduate work in the field. With time, at least some of these students will most likely become career scientists. We expect this impact on the field to continue well beyond the duration of the award.

Thus, during the 3-year award period of this NSF Major Research Instrumentation award, we have (1) increased opportunities for undergraduate students to engage in all aspects of cognitive neuroscience research—from conception and design to presentations and publications, (2) enhanced our curriculum with new courses and an undergraduate minor in cognitive neuroscience to formalize these opportunities, (3) made original contributions to the scientific community and literature, and (4) added students to the pipeline of research scientists. The 3 year award period allowed us to lay the foundation for what we hope to be many years of such outcomes.
